epp:phrases.epp:phrase: Destroy all matching items. Once destroyed the items will be gone forever - this action cannot be undone!
Are you absolutely sure you want to destroy all these items (this action cannot be undone)?
The search expression could not be found - you will need to re-do your search and start again.
You attempted to apply some changes but didn't specify any actions to take?
Applying batch alterations to items (only first shown):
Author in quotations or text extracts

epp:phrase.p: For work being deposited by its own author: In self-archiving this collection of files and associated bibliographic metadata, I grant the right to store them and to make them permanently available publicly for free on-line. I declare that this material is my own intellectual property and I understand that does not assume any responsibility if there is any breach of copyright in distributing these files or metadata. (All authors are urged to prominently assert their copyright on the title page of their work.)

For work being deposited by someone other than its author: I hereby declare that the collection of files and associated bibliographic metadata that I am archiving at ) is in the public domain. If this is not the case, I accept full responsibility for any breach of copyright that distributing these files or metadata may entail.
Clicking on the deposit button indicates your agreement to these terms.

epp:phrases.epp:phrase:
The title of the item. The title should not end with a full stop, but may end with a question mark. There is no way to make italic text, please enter it normally. If you have a subtitle, it should be preceded with a colon [:]. Use capitals only for the first word and for proper nouns.
Example: A brief history of time
Example: Life: an unauthorised biography
Example: Mathematics for engineers and scientists. 5th edition
Example: Ecosystems of the world. Vol. 26. Estuaries of the world

The title of the book, usually found on the title page. The title should not end with a full stop, but may end with a question mark. There is no way to make italic text, please enter it normally. If it has a subtitle, it should be preceded with a colon [:]. Use capitals only for the first word and for proper nouns.
Example: A brief history of time
Example: Life: an unauthorised biography
Example: Mathematics for engineers and scientists. 5th edition
Example: Ecosystems of the world. Vol. 26. Estuaries of the world
A summary of the items content. If the item has a formal abstract then that is what should be entered here. No complicated text formatting is possible.
Natural language terms to describe the content of the item
Companies that are considered authors of this item.

Enter in the format given on the first page or title page. If there are more than four authors, click on the [More input rows] button.
Example: [Smith] [J.P.] [j.smith@soton.ac.uk]
Example: [Chance-Collins] [Chris] [chris@bar.com]
Example: [Fu] [Yan-Li] []
Example: [von Höpfner] [Ludwig G.] []

The total number of pages of the item.
Example: 123

Numerals only. The sequence of pages of the item. Do not enter pp.
Example: 21 to 34

The name of the series to which the document belongs. Enter without punctuation.
Example: Elsevier Oceanography Series

The title of a journal, publication or magazine.
Example: Marine Biology

A person, firm or corporate body responsible for placing an item on the market. Do not use abbreviations, enter in full.
Example: Oxford University Press

Locality of the publisher. Use city or town then country. If city is not known then just use country.
Example: Southampton, UK
Example: Brazil

City or town then country where event was held. If city is not known then just use country.
Example: Rome, Italy
Example: Greece

Start and end dates for the event
Example: 13-15 Dec 2003
Example: 31 Oct - 02 Nov 1999

The title of the conference or workshop.
Example: 11th Conference of Pan-Hellenic Librarians
Example: SIGIR 2001

Unique code identifying a book.
Example: 1 871438 57 8
Example: 067157826X

Unique code identifying a serial.
Example: 1055-0143
Example: 0891-060X
The type of the item presented at a conference or workshop.
Title usually found on the title page (first page of book).

The canonical URL for this item. Some journals require you to provide a link to their version.
Example: http://www.stuffjournal.com/2003/3/
URLs that are related to this item.

Please enter the names of the editors.
This field is required if no creators are listed.
The date this eprint was completed, submitted to a publisher, published or submitted for a Ph.D.
The event to which the date applies.
Enter the volume number of the journal or series in which your item appeared.
Enter the issue number of the journal or series in which your item appeared.
The unique identification number of this item, or a DOI.
The patent application number of this item.
The number, if any, of a technical report or similar item.
Please select the specific type of this monograph.
Please state here whether your deposit has been published, is currently in the process of being published (in press), or has not been previously published.
Please indicate whether this version of the work been refereed below.

epp:phrase.label: Yes, this version has been refereed.
No, this version has not been refereed.

epp:phrases.epp:phrase: You are strongly encouraged to paste in the reference list of your item into the box below. It may be used to link your item to those it cites and to those that cite it.
Please select at least one main subject category, and optionally up to two other subject categories you think are appropriate for your submission, from the list below.

If you think you can specify some useful information about your deposit that can't be entered anywhere else, please enter it here. This information will appear on the public summary page for this item.
Any comments to the editor. This information will not be displayed to the public.

Please enter the department from which the item originated.
Example: School of Electronics and Computer Science

Please enter the institution from which the item originated.
Example: University of Southampton

The name of the applicant to whom the patent was granted. May be a person or an organisation.
Example: Purdue Research Institute
Example: John K. Ducklingson
The contact email address for this item. If the full-text is not available to the public, then requests to view the full-text will be sent to this email. The email address will not be made public.
The sponsoring bodies who contributed funding for the creation of this item.
The names or codes of the projects that created this item.
The divisions with which this item should be associated.

The media of output.
Example: CD-ROM
Example: DVD

The type of the composition
Example: Concerto
Example: Opera
A person, firm or corporate body which holds the copyright for the item.
The pedagogic type that defines the resource.
The approximate learning time required to complete.
Outline of the main purpose of the tasks involved.

The skill areas covered.
Example: Language Learning

The learning level. This should link to a national/international framework to allow easy comparison of resources.
Example: Breakthrough 1-3
Example: GCSE
A book or a conference volume.
A chapter or section in a book.
An article in a journal, magazine, newspaper. Not necessarily peer-reviewed. May be an electronic-only medium, such as an online journal or news website.

A paper, poster, speech, lecture or presentation given at a conference, workshop or other event. If the conference item has been published in a journal or book then please use "Book Section" or "Article" instead.
A monograph. This may be a technical report, project report, documentation, manual, working paper or discussion paper.
A published patent. Do not include as yet unpublished patent applications.
Something within the scope of the repository, but not covered by the other categories.
An artist's artefact or work product.
An artist's exhibition or site specific performance-based deposit.
A digital photograph or visual image.
A bounded collection of quantitative data (e.g. spreadsheet or XML data file).
Experimental data with intermediate analyses and summary results.
Lecture notes, exercises, exam papers or course syllabuses.
Here you can download the entire page to edit offline using editors such as frontpage and re-upload it back into EPrints. Image manipulation is not supported.

epp:phrase.p: As a registered user you will be able to set up saved searches, which are sent when new items are placed in the repository.
Please complete the details on this page to register with .

The registration process uses email to send you details of how to activate your account. You must then check your email and activate your password. Once activated you can start to use the registered features of the repository.
If you have already registered but have forgotten your username or password, click here to set a new password.
You need to register in order to be able to deposit items in the repository.

As a registered user you will be able to manage your items, up to the point of submitting them for Editorial Review. If the review is successful your item will be deposited in the repository, if it is unsuccessful it will be returned to you with editorial comments.
In addition to managing your items a registered user can set up alert options, so that email notifications are sent when new items are placed in the repository.
Please complete the details on this page to register with .

The registration process uses email to send you details of how to activate your account. You must then check your email and activate your password. Once activated you can start to use the registered features of the repository.
If you have already registered but have forgotten your username or password, click here to set a new password.
Unfortunately your item could not be accepted into as-is.
The item has been returned to your workspace. You may wish to edit your item, fix the problem, and redeposit.
Unfortunately your item could not be accepted into as-is.
The item has been deleted.
'' has been deleted from your User Area.
Dear User,
You have requested your email to be changed to
To activate this new address please click here.
Dear User,
Thank you for your interest in .
You now need to activate your password. This will expire in .
Your username is: .
After you have successfully confirmed your password, you can deposit items here.

Once you have confirmed your identity you may also subscribe to the email alerts service, to be automatically informed of new deposits in the repository in your chosen subject areas in a daily, weekly or monthly digest.
Have your username and password ready when visiting any of the above pages.
This message was generated automatically by software. If you have any questions, then please feel free to email a real person at:
Contact us at

epp:phrases.epp:phrase: Metadata field properties have sensible defaults that can be overriden by specifying a value on this page. If you wish to use the default leave the value as UNSPECIFIED.
The metadata field name you specified already exists in this dataset.

epp:phrase.p: Note: For this to work the web server must have write access to the var, phrases and workflow directories for this repository.

When you commit this new metadata field its configuration will be written to the metadata fields configuration file and the appropriate columns added to the database. If you specified a name and help phrase for this field they will be added to the fields.xml phrases file for each language you specified (see also the phrases documentation).
If this field is being added to the Eprints dataset it will also be added to the Eprints submission workflow (see also the workflow documentation).
To make use of your new field (e.g. by adding it to the abstract page) look at HOW TO: Add a New Field.
If you don't want to add a new field now click Save for Later.

epp:phrases.epp:phrase: Failed to add this field's phrase, you should check that your phrases directory is writable.
Failed to add this field to the workflow, you should check that your workflow directory is writable.

This tool allows you to add metadata fields to your repository. Only fields added using this tool can be removed by this tool. To start configuring fields choose a dataset to add/remove fields from the following list.
The name of a field must contain only the letters a-z and underscore (requested name was "")
The field "" you are attempting to modify doesn't appear to be configured for the dataset "" (perhaps it's a system field?).

You are about to edit the configuration and database settings for the field in the dataset. You may permanently lose data any stored in ! If you are sure this is what you want to do click the confirm button.

You are about to remove the configuration and database settings for the field in the dataset. This means you will permanently lose any data stored in ! If you are sure this is what you want to do click the confirm button.
Added the configuration and database settings for the field in the dataset.
Removed the configuration and database settings for the field in the dataset.
Renamed old field in the configuration and database settings to in the dataset.
Failed to remove the field. You should ensure the web server has write access to the fields configuration file for this repository.
An integer that will automatically increase by 1 for every new object.
A date/time that will automatically be initialised to the current date/time.
Select from a list of configured languages in the repository.
A container for other fields. The interface for adding compound fields is complex and may allow you to create an inconsistent configuration, use with care!
Select from a list of fields in a data set.
Select a file from the user's file system.
A reference to another object in the repository.
A large text field (more than 255 characters).

A multi-lingual field behaves the same as a Compound field but always has a "lang" sub-field that is a set of the currently configured languages. Use this type of field to allow users to enter metadata in more than one language.
The name of a person, consisting of honourific, given, family and lineage parts.
A Set that takes its values from a namedset file.
A Set of values to choose from (if you are likely to ever change the set of values use namedset instead).
Choose a value from the subjects hierarchy.
The human-readable name of this field - will be shown above the field input.
The optional help text to show for this field.
Select the fields you would like to use as part of this compound field.
The name of a field should be made up of lowercase English letters.

Choose from the available metadata field types to determine the type of information you want to capture. The field type will determine the form elements used, data constraints and rendering in Web pages.
Compound and Multilang are special fields that allow you to combine multiple sub-fields in a logical fashion (for instance "name" and "email"). The way fields behave can be refined by using properties.
For more information see MetaFields.
Specify the type of data the field will contain. The available types are defined by MetaField classes.
Whether the user is required to enter data for this field (may be overridden in the workflow).
Whether this field should allow more than one value.
Whether this field can be undefined (NULL) in the database.
Whether this field should be exported in EPrints XML. You may not want to export things like passwords or other sensitive data.
By default any changes to an object will trigger a new revision of that object. By setting a field as volatile changes made just to volatile fields will not cause new revisions to occur.
Whether this field should have a database index added to it.
The name of a custom input render function.
The name of a custom render function.
Set to true if the order of the values is important (applicable to multiple fields).
Maximum number of characters to allow the user to enter. Use input_cols to control the size of the form input control.
When rendering values you can add a link on the value to the browse view pages. Specify the name of the view to link the value to - this will depend on the views you have defined.
Top element of the subject hierarchy to show.
The repository dataset to link the object identifier to (e.g. "eprint").
The name of the file to read the option values from (in /cfg/namedsets).
A comma-separated list of values to choose from (e.g. london,paris,new_york)). You will need to create phrases for every defined option.
The order to render the name value in (family, given or given family).
Hide the honourific name part in the submission workflow.
Hide the lineage name part in the submission workflow.
Whether to show the family first in the submission workflow.
Input style of the set selector.
Input rows to show (lines of text, or options visible).
Input columns to show (columns of text). To restrict the maximum number of characters entered for text fields use the maxlength property.
Starting number of input rows to show (if field is multiple). As users add values more rows will be shown.
The name of the counter used to get the next incremented value, must be made up of lowercase English characters or underscore.
Unspecified or unknown dataset id "" given
Check that you have entered the same secret twice.
Full text not available from this repository.

p.em: This is the latest version of this item.

A (pseudo) unique ID suggested by the client when depositing through SWORD
You haven't specified a document type!
You need to select a file to be shown first.

epp:phrase.p: The amount of disk space available for new EPrints has dropped below the repository threshold. New disk space will be needed soon.
If you get sick of this message, lower the "diskspace_warn_threshold" in the config file. If you do this then don't forget to put it back after you add more disk space.
The usual way to add disk space is to symlink a directory on a new drive into the repository "documents" directory.
There are no available partitions with enough disk space to create new items. This needs sorting out urgently.
NO NEW ITEMS WILL BE ADDED UNTIL YOU FIX THIS.
To add more capacity, symlink a directory on a new drive into the repository "documents" directory.

epp:phrase.p: There is a problem with the form:
The search failed to execute correctly.

epp:phrases.epp:phrase: A year search must be specified as a single year, e.g. `2000', or a range of years, e.g. `1990-2000', `1990-' or `-2000'
A numerical search must be specified as a single integer number, e.g. `23', or a range of numbers, e.g. `9-21', `17-' or `-93'
A date search must be specified as a single date or a range.
Search field contains no indexable words: "". The system ignores very small or common words.
Enter some text to search for.
Select one or more values from the list. Default is (Any).
Enter a term or terms to search for.

Enter a name or names to search for. Either the family name, or the family name followed by a comma and the first name or initial. Names with spaces may be indicated by surrounding them with double quotes, eg. "van Damme, J".
Select one or more values from the list, and whether you want to search for records with any one or all of those values. Default is (Any).
Select one or more values from the list, and whether you want to search for records with any one or all of those values. Default is (Any).
Select one or more values from the list, and whether you want to search for records with any one or all of those values. Default is (Any).
Enter one or more usernames (space separated) and whether you want to search for records with any one or all of those values. Default is (Any).
Enter a term or terms to search for.
Enter a term or terms to search for.
Enter an exact term to search for.
Enter a term or terms to search for.
Enter some text to search for.
Enter a single year (e.g. 1999), or a range of years, e.g. `1990-2000', `1990-' or -2000'.
Enter a single number (e.g. 93), or a range of numbers, e.g. `17-23', `17-' or -23'.
Enter a single number (e.g. 3.14159), or a range of numbers, e.g. `4.8-15', `16-' or -23.42'.
Select a single record ID number (e.g. 93), or a range of numbers, e.g. `17-23', `17-' or -23'.

epp:phrase.p: Here are the documents currently attached to this item, and how many files you have uploaded for each.

epp:phrase.p: Please enter the URL of the item you wish to upload to the repository in the box below.

Occasionally, uploading this way may not produce a totally accurate copy. This is because some assumptions about the structure of the HTML must be made, to stop the software from trying to upload the whole World-Wide Web!
Enter the filename (with full path) of the compressed file in the box below.
Please enter the filename (with full path) of the document file in the box below.
Please enter the filenames (with full paths) of the document files in the boxes below.

epp:phrases.epp:phrase: Before you deposit this entry into the repository, the following problems need to be corrected:

epp:phrase.p: Please verify that all of the details about your deposit are correct, and that all necessary files have been correctly uploaded including any figures.
When you are satisfied click the Deposit Item Now button at the foot of this page.
Thank you.
Your submission will now be held for review. Provided there are no problems it should appear in the repository within the next few days.
